DOC.HEAD: Interim Prime Minister Faces Enormous Tasks
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Petre Roman, Romania's interim prime minister, is a young intellectual who faces the daunting task of finding ways to mend a country torn by bloody strife and a battered economy. ``It's clear that our difficulties are great,'' Roman told Soviet television in an interview Tuesday.``The greater part of the cadres we need for our economy have not yet resumed their work.'' The 43-year-old university professor said he and the rest of the 37 members of the National Salvation Committee, Romania's main organ of power since the Dec. 22 toppling of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, have not had time to examine what exactly to do about the economy. ``What we have achieved so far is to solve only emergency problems,'' Roman told the Vremya news program. ``The questions I'll be dealing with are connected with restoration of the economy under new conditions.'' Romania was badly mishandled during Ceausescu's rule, leading to widespread shortages of basic foodstuffs, commodities and energy. Ceausescu, who rejected the kind of reforms under way elsewhere in the Soviet bloc, advocated a Stalinist-type centrally planned economy, entirely disregarding market forces and outlawing private property. In another interview Tuesday with French television, Roman said the reason for executing Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, only two days after their capture was that the Council feared Ceausescu's secret police were planning a rescue attempt. Roman graduated from the Faculty of Hydromechanics of the Polytechnic Institute in Bucharest, where he now is a professor. He did post-graduate work at the National Polytechnic Institute in Toulouse, France, where he graduated magna cum laude. He is married and the father of two children. Roman's late father Valter was a prominent sociologist who fought in Spain against anti-Franco forces during the Spanish Civil War. His mother, Hortensia, now retired, for years had a high-level post at the state-run Radio Bucharest.
